Observation Details: Cet individu était vraiment spécial, nous l'avons aperçu en parade sur un tronc au detour d'un sentier. Nous nous sommes arrêtés pour le photographier, mais à notre plus grand étonnement il a cessé sa parade et au lieu de fuir est venu à notre rencontre! Il se promenait autour à moins d'un pied de nous et nous observait de façon très curieuse. Il nous a suivi comme un chien en marchant à côté de nous sur plusieurs dizaines de mètres... Il a cessé de nous suivre quand le sentier à débouché sur la plage...

Observation Details: Incredible encounter with one aggressive male!!! Stopped to listen to singing warblers only to be approached by a clucking male. After a few minutes of him following me around, I sat down to try and photograph him only to have him hop up on my legs! I sat with the bird for about 20 minutes before he began to get aggressive, prompting me to leave him alone. At one point he proceeded to take a big dump, luckily right off of my knee, narrowly missing me. What an awesome bird encounter.

Locality: 901–1099 Butter Bowl Rd, Cherry Valley US-NY 42.76490, -74.81058

Observation Details: A nearly unbelievable find! The grouse was first found this morning and then relocated this evening along the entrance road about 100m west of the Quarry Trailhead entrance. As I walked along the road towards the group supposedly watching the grouse I was looking in the bushes on both sides of the road, searching for any sign of the grouse. To my great surprise, the Ruffed Grouse was actually sitting on the concrete barrier on the side of the road less than five feet away from the group. As I got out my camera to take some photos the grouse actually walked towards me and got even closer until it was only about two feet away. Many thanks to Melissa Hafting for refinding the bird and then waiting with it until I arrived so I could find it so easily. It seems ridiculous, but Ruffed Grouse has been a bird that I've been looking for for more than five years; I've been all over B.C. and even to Ontario in my search, and I've been as close as hearing them fly away from me only a few metres away on multiple occasions, so to finally see my lifer Ruffed Grouse actually in Vancouver and in such a remarkable manner is really as special as it gets.

Wow! Absolutely beautiful bird. First found by Simon Bernard at around 9:45am in the morning, and was not seen until relocated by Melissa Hafting et al along Quarry Road. Extremely tame and walked along the road and even territorial at some points (chasing me and others). Much smaller than a SOGR, brown, with elegant and detailed patterning on the belly. Often sat on the traffic barrier only feet away from me. Almost 100% a female. Ruffed Grouse have been extirpated from Metro Vancouver for more than two decades, so an appearance here is rare and a sign that they may be making a comeback! Seen and photographed by many.

Locality: Cornell University - Fall Creek Suspension Bridge
Observation Details: Pecking around the non-campus entrance to the suspension bridge. Eventually flew up to 302 (I believe) directly across from the entrance and fed on buds in the yard. Eventually attempted to fly up onto the roof, but it was too steep and slippery, so the bird flapped around and fell. After that it perched on a lamp for a minute or two before hopping down and preening.
three birds feeding together at the edge of a campsite; photographed

Male heard drumming near camp from day #1 and first identified by Simon Marcel. Later that day Simone Littledale, Carter Strope and I went bushwacking in search of the bird and were able to find its drumming spot, a partially decayed moss covered log laden with some kind of shelf mushroom. Though we didn't see it drum there as it walked off after we found it, Carter noted a pile of scat at that exact spot which he thought indicated this was a display site rather just a perch. Later in camp when we told the others, Joachim Bertrands had the idea based on his guiding work in Borneo with Bird-of-Paradise lek hides to build a hide so we could view the grouse drumming up-close. That evening Simon, Carter, Joachim, Aiva and I went off and constructed a hide out of sword fern and fir branches, with some very conveniently salvaged netting which just happened to be within 5 feet of the blind spot. We also cleared a small trail leading to the blind of any twigs and sticks which might crack underfoot and give us away.  Day #2 a number of us quietly snuck into place with great anticipation and found the grouse perched on its log. In a very cool turn of events though, while waiting silently, a Pacific Marten came in nearly over our heads and sprinted over to the log, flushing the grouse which seemed at the time (and we later confirmed) to have gotten away unscathed. A few other attempts were made throughout the day to see if the bird returned which it did periodically, and late that evening Carter was able to see it drum before a Goshawk buzzed overhead.  Day #3 some of us had already headed back to Victoria while other (read; nearly all) of us were fighting wicked hangovers and not inclined to go stakeout a blind at the crack of dawn. Fueled by ire, Redbull (sponsor me), and being able to clearly hear the bird drumming from my tent, I went out on my own, going in barefoot so as to make as little noise as possible. The bird was there, the blind was effective, and I think the videos below speak for themself.  Really enjoyed getting to crack the code on Ruffed Grouse with my friends and excited to see if I can't replicate this again in other areas!
mostly on the ground, one flew to tree; one was male started courtship until startled

Observation Details: Merci à Réal et Ghyslaine Boulet pour cette découverte d'une Gélinotte huppée qui n'a jamais craint d'être observée par des humains. Elle a passé la journée le long de la route à manger des bourgeons dans les arbrisseaux au moins jusqu'en fin pm. Elle était également présente au même endroit la veille mais je ne l'ai par revue le lendemain.  Il s'agit d'un mâle adulte: huppe marquée, taches blanches en double sur le croupion (ici formant un coeur), collerette noire importante (ici repliée), ligne blanche qui part du lorum jusque derrière l'oeil, bande noire terminale qui n'est pas interrompue au centre par les rectrices centrales (qui sont mouchetés chez la femelle).

Observation Details: We were near our cabin in the woods.  We noticed the female RUGR walking away from us, then we looked closer near the area and saw her nest on the ground, with chicks in the process of hatching, and two hopping near the nest.  We left to give them space.  A few hours later we looked again and saw the nest with all eggs open and the birds had left the nest site.

Locality: Club de ski de fond Rapido

Observation Details: Cooperative but at times aggressive male. The bird didn't seem too aggressive while I was crouched down and facing it but when standing up and facing away the bird would chase me and occasionally jump at me, trying to peck and wing-slap me. I only stayed to record and photograph the bird for a few minutes as I didn't want to disturb it more than necessary, but it made it very difficult to leave. After I got in the car it went around and underneath the car for a few minutes but eventually went back to the edge of the road to forage. As soon as we started the car and began to move though, it ran directly at the car and started chasing alongside it so we had to stop as to not risk hitting it with one of the tires. I got out and was able to lure the bird towards me and away from the car before running back, hopping in, and driving away. The bird trailed behind the car (this time at a safe distance) for a few seconds before stopping when we got far enough away.

Female ruffed grouse appeared in the lawn, attracted to the sound of my mower. 1/2 hr later, it appeared again, attracted to my tractor. When I turned the tractor off, it continued to stay and made mating gestures toward me. I had to scare it away (it didn't go far) and go inside. It very likely would have followed me in the house. I made a video of it but don't think I can share that on ebird?

Wow! Absolutely beautiful bird. First found by Simon Bernard at around 9:45am in the morning, and was not seen until relocated by Melissa Hafting et al along Quarry Road. Extremely tame and walked along the road and even territorial at some points (chasing me and others). Much smaller than a SOGR, brown, with elegant and detailed patterning on the belly. Often sat on the traffic barrier only feet away from me. Almost 100% a female. Ruffed Grouse have been extirpated from Metro Vancouver for more than two decades, so an appearance here is rare and a sign that they may be making a comeback! Seen and photographed by many.

The bird then circled around a few feet from his car on the passenger side, moving in front of his car. Then it proceeded to go behind mine and loop around to the front. Then it crossed the road providing for great shots. Did this 3 times (looping around us), and eventually wandered back off into the woods. This all happened just before the old well. Additionally I later had a drumming individual further up the road. Drumming in 4 min intervals by telephone pole #664

I originally reported this bird in 2012, but it was not confirmed. This time I am adding some more details so that it will hopefully be confirmed.   Original report: http://ebird.org/ebird/view/checklist?subID=S19364205  The most amazing and unbelievable part about this was that we found its nest. The grouse was flushed and easily identified. Loud powerful and fast wingbeats with the obvious black tail band. No other bird is the size of a Ruffed Grouse in the area and nothing else looks quite like a grouse around here. Very easily identified. Two photos were taken of the nest. Ruffed Grouse were spotted several times around this date in the vicinity. Also, our woods are as good as it gets for grouse habitat.   On a sad note, around this time a Ruffed Grouse flew into out French door on the back porch and died. Photos were taken of it.   Now in 2015 we have not seen a Ruffed Grouse since 2012. It is really disappointing to see this species disappear from the area as it was a specialty of our woods.
This one maintained a hidden status popping its head up a few times to look around.

This Ruffed Grouse was fairly small  with a short, triangular crest and a long, fan-shaped tail. Short legs walking on snow.  It was intricately patterned with dark bars and spots on either a reddish-brown or grayish background. Black plumage down the side of the neck continue onto the body  belly. The tail is finely barred, with one wide, black band near the tip. The bird was found at Robert Shaw's house. Territorial ad aggressive.

Locality: Area around Jenny Lake, Grand Teton National Park

Observation Details: Ruffed Grouse!!!  This was a PHENOMENALLY close (lifer) encounter with a very special species for Indiana. I sincerely hope this isn’t the only Ruffed Grouse I see here in my lifetime. Jonathan and I shared the experience with our buds, Kris and Logan Lakins, and coincidentally, three other birders (Mona C., Chris N., and Jeremiah O.). No planned “field trip.”  We spent over 2 hours searching the area for the grouse without luck. We were already on the road when Jeremiah messaged he had it, and then we turned around and rushed back up the path on foot. The lapse in time between calling off the search and heading back to the location was about 20 minutes. The experience was breathtaking — and not for the running/speed-walking!  Description… Brighter rufous coloration on the tail and neck. Thick black subterminal stripe on a long tail. Vertical black barring on its sides with white between. Chestnut eyes with super cool “eyelashes.” Gorgeous bird in general. The most ornately spangle-patterned brown back I’ve ever seen. Looking closely, there were little cream-colored hearts on its back. Black feathers around the long neck feathers that looked like a flattened ruff. Size-wise, it was surprisingly bigger than I thought it would be; bigger than a Bobwhite. It was remarkably camouflaged from a distance. I believe the bird we saw to be a male due to the unbroken black stripe on its long tail.  Behavior… When we saw the Ruffed Grouse, it was walking on the forest floor about 15 feet away from us. It stayed flightless the entire time. It frequently called quietly, making some “pew” calls in twos and threes and single cat-like purrs (whuuuut!). The bird perched on a fallen log to watch us before approaching; it got within two feet of our group while we stood quietly in place at the forested edge. The Brown County Epic, a mountain-biking event, was happening while we were there, so two to three cyclists would occasionally pass by and spook the grouse further back into the woods. We didn’t even need our binoculars. Unbelievable. It played Inspector Jacques Clouseau with us and every now and again would grab and yeet leaves. I’m honestly flabbergasted by the inquisitiveness of this bird.  Habitat… mature forest with mixed hardwoods. I noticed lots of tulip poplars, shagbark hickory, and maples and plenty of debris/bark on the ground and understory. My tree ID is limited, though.  Our observation was from a stationary position. I made brief descriptive notes on my phone in the field and typed up more details later that evening. Our time was spent solely with the grouse, hence the low count for other species. I logged others earlier while searching (https://ebird.org/checklist/S120204215). The grouse experience filled my cup, so to speak, so much so that I didn’t go birding again for days. The rabbit hole of learning more about this species kept me delightfully occupied.  This checklist was hidden from output for a month, honoring the request of the person who relocated the/a previously reported grouse and shared the information confidentially. I didn’t make the rules.

Locality: Grand Teton NP—Two Ocean Lake Rd pullout

Observation Details: "Casper the friendly grouse" continues! He didn't show up until I was getting ready to leave (naturally), but once he was there he was extraordinarily confiding, at one point he was following me like a little puppy. He was oddly very challenging to photograph being so close.

Cooperative but at times aggressive male. The bird didn't seem too aggressive while I was crouched down and facing it but when standing up and facing away the bird would chase me and occasionally jump at me, trying to peck and wing-slap me. I only stayed to record and photograph the bird for a few minutes as I didn't want to disturb it more than necessary, but it made it very difficult to leave. After I got in the car it went around and underneath the car for a few minutes but eventually went back to the edge of the road to forage. As soon as we started the car and began to move though, it ran directly at the car and started chasing alongside it so we had to stop as to not risk hitting it with one of the tires. I got out and was able to lure the bird towards me and away from the car before running back, hopping in, and driving away. The bird trailed behind the car (this time at a safe distance) for a few seconds before stopping when we got far enough away.

This is a bird I will never forget. As soon as I pulled up around the bend, it came running out of the woods towards my car. After that, it would not leave my side for the next 45 minutes (except for when I sprinted away, then it decided it could eat some leaves on the side of the road). This bird gets so close to you that you have to use the widest angle lens on your phone if you want to photograph it at eye level. It also did hit me once which was upsetting.

Observation Details: After bumping into John Marshall he said that he had one drumming just up the road. While catching up on the birds we’ve been seeing, I go to him: “Well there ya go, the grouse is behind your car”. The bird then circled around a few feet from his car on the passenger side, moving in front of his car. Then it proceeded to go behind mine and loop around to the front. Then it crossed the road providing for great shots. Did this 3 times (looping around us), and eventually wandered back off into the woods. This all happened just before the old well. Additionally I later had a drumming individual further up the road. Drumming in 4 min intervals by telephone pole #664

A nearly unbelievable find! The grouse was first found this morning and then relocated this evening along the entrance road about 100m west of the Quarry Trailhead entrance. As I walked along the road towards the group supposedly watching the grouse I was looking in the bushes on both sides of the road, searching for any sign of the grouse. To my great surprise, the Ruffed Grouse was actually sitting on the concrete barrier on the side of the road less than five feet away from the group. As I got out my camera to take some photos the grouse actually walked towards me and got even closer until it was only about two feet away. Many thanks to Melissa Hafting for refinding the bird and then waiting with it until I arrived so I could find it so easily. It seems ridiculous, but Ruffed Grouse has been a bird that I've been looking for for more than five years; I've been all over B.C. and even to Ontario in my search, and I've been as close as hearing them fly away from me only a few metres away on multiple occasions, so to finally see my lifer Ruffed Grouse actually in Vancouver and in such a remarkable manner is really as special as it gets.

Ruffed Grouse!!!  This was a PHENOMENALLY close (lifer) encounter with a very special species for Indiana. I sincerely hope this isn’t the only Ruffed Grouse I see here in my lifetime. Jonathan and I shared the experience with our buds, Kris and Logan Lakins, and coincidentally, three other birders (Mona C., Chris N., and Jeremiah O.). No planned “field trip.”  We spent over 2 hours searching the area for the grouse without luck. We were already on the road when Jeremiah messaged he had it, and then we turned around and rushed back up the path on foot. The lapse in time between calling off the search and heading back to the location was about 20 minutes. The experience was breathtaking — and not for the running/speed-walking!  Description… Brighter rufous coloration on the tail and neck. Thick black subterminal stripe on a long tail. Vertical black barring on its sides with white between. Chestnut eyes with super cool “eyelashes.” Gorgeous bird in general. The most ornately spangle-patterned brown back I’ve ever seen. Looking closely, there were little cream-colored hearts on its back. Black feathers around the long neck feathers that looked like a flattened ruff. Size-wise, it was surprisingly bigger than I thought it would be; bigger than a Bobwhite. It was remarkably camouflaged from a distance. I believe the bird we saw to be a male due to the unbroken black stripe on its long tail.  Behavior… When we saw the Ruffed Grouse, it was walking on the forest floor about 15 feet away from us. It stayed flightless the entire time. It frequently called quietly, making some “pew” calls in twos and threes and single cat-like purrs (whuuuut!). The bird perched on a fallen log to watch us before approaching; it got within two feet of our group while we stood quietly in place at the forested edge. The Brown County Epic, a mountain-biking event, was happening while we were there, so two to three cyclists would occasionally pass by and spook the grouse further back into the woods. We didn’t even need our binoculars. Unbelievable. It played Inspector Jacques Clouseau with us and every now and again would grab and yeet leaves. I’m honestly flabbergasted by the inquisitiveness of this bird.  Habitat… mature forest with mixed hardwoods. I noticed lots of tulip poplars, shagbark hickory, and maples and plenty of debris/bark on the ground and understory. My tree ID is limited, though.  Our observation was from a stationary position. I made brief descriptive notes on my phone in the field and typed up more details later that evening. Our time was spent solely with the grouse, hence the low count for other species. I logged others earlier while searching (https://ebird.org/checklist/S120204215). The grouse experience filled my cup, so to speak, so much so that I didn’t go birding again for days. The rabbit hole of learning more about this species kept me delightfully occupied.  This checklist was hidden from output for a month, honoring the request of the person who relocated the/a previously reported grouse and shared the information confidentially. I didn’t make the rules.

Locality: Cape Breton Highlands NP--Warren Lake Trail

Observation Details: Cooperative but at times aggressive male. The bird didn't seem too aggressive while I was crouched down and facing it but when standing up and facing away the bird would chase me and occasionally jump at me, trying to peck and wing-slap me. I only stayed to record and photograph the bird for a few minutes as I didn't want to disturb it more than necessary, but it made it very difficult to leave. After I got in the car it went around and underneath the car for a few minutes but eventually went back to the edge of the road to forage. As soon as we started the car and began to move though, it ran directly at the car and started chasing alongside it so we had to stop as to not risk hitting it with one of the tires. I got out and was able to lure the bird towards me and away from the car before running back, hopping in, and driving away. The bird trailed behind the car (this time at a safe distance) for a few seconds before stopping when we got far enough away.

I stopped and the bird walked along the road past the car, stopping near the right rear tire. When I pulled slowly forward the bird chased the car. When I got out of the car to take a photo, the bird began to pursue me, pecking at my shoes. It did not flee even when I approached it, but continued it’s aggressive behavior until I backed away.
Quite tame and repeatedly walked very close to me. Did not appear injured.

Continuing; male. Roosting about 6-7 feet up in a spruce. Photos.  Ruffed Grouse were introduced into the Mat-Su Valley in 1988 and have spread considerably since then. They are now regular in Talkeetna, the outskirts of the Municipality of Anchorage, and out towards Chickaloon/Glacier View. They even turn up in the Anchorage bowl about annually. According to Tony, they have been in the Peters Creek drainage for at least 15 years. This is all to say, any of the birds in this general area are introduced, but almost certainly established (my humble opinion).

Observation Details: Incredible encounter with one aggressive male!!! Stopped to listen to singing warblers only to be approached by a clucking male. After a few minutes of him following me around, I sat down to try and photograph him only to have him hop up on my legs! I sat with the bird for about 20 minutes before he began to get aggressive, prompting me to leave him alone. At one point he proceeded to take a big dump, luckily right off of my knee, narrowly missing me. What an awesome bird encounter.

A nearly unbelievable find! The grouse was first found this morning and then relocated this evening along the entrance road about 100m west of the Quarry Trailhead entrance. As I walked along the road towards the group supposedly watching the grouse I was looking in the bushes on both sides of the road, searching for any sign of the grouse. To my great surprise, the Ruffed Grouse was actually sitting on the concrete barrier on the side of the road less than five feet away from the group. As I got out my camera to take some photos the grouse actually walked towards me and got even closer until it was only about two feet away. Many thanks to Melissa Hafting for refinding the bird and then waiting with it until I arrived so I could find it so easily. It seems ridiculous, but Ruffed Grouse has been a bird that I've been looking for for more than five years; I've been all over B.C. and even to Ontario in my search, and I've been as close as hearing them fly away from me only a few metres away on multiple occasions, so to finally see my lifer Ruffed Grouse actually in Vancouver and in such a remarkable manner is really as special as it gets.

Observation Details: Wow! Absolutely beautiful bird. First found by Simon Bernard at around 9:45am in the morning, and was not seen until relocated by Melissa Hafting et al along Quarry Road. Extremely tame and walked along the road and even territorial at some points (chasing me and others). Much smaller than a SOGR, brown, with elegant and detailed patterning on the belly. Often sat on the traffic barrier only feet away from me. Almost 100% a female. Ruffed Grouse have been extirpated from Metro Vancouver for more than two decades, so an appearance here is rare and a sign that they may be making a comeback! Seen and photographed by many.

Observation Details: Crazy experience with this Ruffed Grouse.  I originally saw it on the side of the road and I thought that it may have been hit by a car so I thought that I would see if if was OK.  It became very territorial and became aggressive.  It began to hiss at me and lunged at me a couple of times.  It began to fan out completely and both ruffs on the neck became exposed.  I came back through about an hour later and it was gone at that point.  But an amazing experience of a territorial display.  Pretty cool.

A Ruffed Grouse flushed from the understory along the trail to the Academy Mill Reservoir. It perched in a tree along the trail and froze, apparently depending on its camouflage. I have seen Ruffed Grouse do this twice before in my experienc with them here in central Utah. A second grouse flushed and flew away.

Observation Details: The first grouse flushed and then landed, was still for several seconds, and then raised its crest and ruff and spread its tail. The second flushed about a mile farther along. I was able to watch it fliy off and noted its size, color, and the dark band on its tail. Ruffed Grouse a native to this area. They breed here. I have heard them drumming and seen them with young. This species should be on the Sanpete County checklist.

Observation Details: Male heard drumming near camp from day #1 and first identified by Simon Marcel. Later that day Simone Littledale, Carter Strope and I went bushwacking in search of the bird and were able to find its drumming spot, a partially decayed moss covered log laden with some kind of shelf mushroom. Though we didn't see it drum there as it walked off after we found it, Carter noted a pile of scat at that exact spot which he thought indicated this was a display site rather just a perch. Later in camp when we told the others, Joachim Bertrands had the idea based on his guiding work in Borneo with Bird-of-Paradise lek hides to build a hide so we could view the grouse drumming up-close. That evening Simon, Carter, Joachim, Aiva and I went off and constructed a hide out of sword fern and fir branches, with some very conveniently salvaged netting which just happened to be within 5 feet of the blind spot. We also cleared a small trail leading to the blind of any twigs and sticks which might crack underfoot and give us away.  Day #2 a number of us quietly snuck into place with great anticipation and found the grouse perched on its log. In a very cool turn of events though, while waiting silently, a Pacific Marten came in nearly over our heads and sprinted over to the log, flushing the grouse which seemed at the time (and we later confirmed) to have gotten away unscathed. A few other attempts were made throughout the day to see if the bird returned which it did periodically, and late that evening Carter was able to see it drum before a Goshawk buzzed overhead.  Day #3 some of us had already headed back to Victoria while other (read; nearly all) of us were fighting wicked hangovers and not inclined to go stakeout a blind at the crack of dawn. Fueled by ire, Redbull (sponsor me), and being able to clearly hear the bird drumming from my tent, I went out on my own, going in barefoot so as to make as little noise as possible. The bird was there, the blind was effective, and I think the videos below speak for themself.  Really enjoyed getting to crack the code on Ruffed Grouse with my friends and excited to see if I can't replicate this again in other areas!

Locality: Quartier le Radar, La Tuque CA-QC (47.9022,-74.6523)

Observation Details: I was probably there an hour before I found the grouse (my first time finding a grouse here, after missing multiple times last year).  One of the more memorable, cool, and yet weird bird experiences I've had. Although originally he was about 25' back in the woods (after I'd been looking for probably an hour), the grouse came gradually closer, eventually close enough that I could have touched him. Other than going nearer to the road's edge when he was 25' deep in the woods, I didn't approach him, but he approached me. He definitely started following me--at first, feeding quietly through the woods and walking the same way I did, then when I turned around and walked back (to see what he'd do), he turned around and followed me. Once he came out into the road, he definitely followed me--and I had to be very careful when I left, to be sure he was away from my car and back in the woods. Many photos, audio.

Observation Details: Cette gélinotte suit les humains qui se présentent dans le sentier sur une distance de 100m. S'approche de très près si on cesse de marcher et se laisse facilement photographier. Elle attaque si on est à moins de 30cm d'elle. Émet des sons de type gloussements divers et des plaintes langoureuses si on s'assoit trop près. Femelle présumée en raison de l'absence de collerette, l'absence de plumes en forme de coeur sur le croupion et le cri

Unfortunately, the next day there was only a pile of feathers in that area.

Continuing. Mottled/striped White/tan/ rusty/brown/black uppers. Dark eye. Anterior throat/ chin/upper chest golden tan. Decurved bill. Small white patch behind eye & along bill. Rusty tail terminal black>/white thin bands. Slightly spiky crown. Vertical white lateral striPing. By Linda. Will add photos. Grouse may have been under the blind when we arrived. It walked out towards me from the far side of the blind and I eased to the ground, staying still. It wasn’t aggressive but walked across the path slowly. We stayed quiet as it foraged a bit. Bikers and another birder did get its attention, but it was never aggressive. What a memorable few minutes for a life bird for me. Susan

For the second day in a row I've come across Ruffed Grouse. This bird on the Claryville Road. The bird was quite accommodating and remained in the road without flushing. I walked around and took a number of photos, halting an oncoming car. The woman was very nice and happy to oblige. Eventually, as I heard a second car coming, I flushed the bird from the road so it wouldn't get hit.

Observation Details: Ruffed Grouse!!!  This was a PHENOMENALLY close (lifer) encounter with a very special species for Indiana. I sincerely hope this isn’t the only Ruffed Grouse I see here in my lifetime. Jonathan and I shared the experience with our buds, Kris and Logan Lakins, and coincidentally, three other birders (Mona C., Chris N., and Jeremiah O.). No planned “field trip.”  We spent over 2 hours searching the area for the grouse without luck. We were already on the road when Jeremiah messaged he had it, and then we turned around and rushed back up the path on foot. The lapse in time between calling off the search and heading back to the location was about 20 minutes. The experience was breathtaking — and not for the running/speed-walking!  Description… Brighter rufous coloration on the tail and neck. Thick black subterminal stripe on a long tail. Vertical black barring on its sides with white between. Chestnut eyes with super cool “eyelashes.” Gorgeous bird in general. The most ornately spangle-patterned brown back I’ve ever seen. Looking closely, there were little cream-colored hearts on its back. Black feathers around the long neck feathers that looked like a flattened ruff. Size-wise, it was surprisingly bigger than I thought it would be; bigger than a Bobwhite. It was remarkably camouflaged from a distance. I believe the bird we saw to be a male due to the unbroken black stripe on its long tail.  Behavior… When we saw the Ruffed Grouse, it was walking on the forest floor about 15 feet away from us. It stayed flightless the entire time. It frequently called quietly, making some “pew” calls in twos and threes and single cat-like purrs (whuuuut!). The bird perched on a fallen log to watch us before approaching; it got within two feet of our group while we stood quietly in place at the forested edge. The Brown County Epic, a mountain-biking event, was happening while we were there, so two to three cyclists would occasionally pass by and spook the grouse further back into the woods. We didn’t even need our binoculars. Unbelievable. It played Inspector Jacques Clouseau with us and every now and again would grab and yeet leaves. I’m honestly flabbergasted by the inquisitiveness of this bird.  Habitat… mature forest with mixed hardwoods. I noticed lots of tulip poplars, shagbark hickory, and maples and plenty of debris/bark on the ground and understory. My tree ID is limited, though.  Our observation was from a stationary position. I made brief descriptive notes on my phone in the field and typed up more details later that evening. Our time was spent solely with the grouse, hence the low count for other species. I logged others earlier while searching (https://ebird.org/checklist/S120204215). The grouse experience filled my cup, so to speak, so much so that I didn’t go birding again for days. The rabbit hole of learning more about this species kept me delightfully occupied.  This checklist was hidden from output for a month, honoring the request of the person who relocated the/a previously reported grouse and shared the information confidentially. I didn’t make the rules.
Recently seen past several months in this area.  It came to the road and hung out with me and made noises for a while. Within inches of me at all times.

The habitat was dense, thick, low understory, a little over halfway from the trailhead to Lower Palisades Lake. I was walking back down the trail when I heard a strange, novel whining sound. Looked up to see what I thought at first was a hurt badger limping down the trail. When it lifted its head, I realized it was a grouse. As soon as this clicked, baby grouse began to flush out of the understory. I now realized the grouse was luring me away from its young. I didn't budge, and proceeded to take camera shots. The grouse did not like this. He turned, fanned his tail, activated his 'gills", and charged me. I held my ground, and amid my terror, managed to snap a couple photos. He slammed on the brakes less than 10 feet away, then proceeded to  try luring me away again. This time I obliged. After 100-150 feet or so, he turned off the trail into the understory, making a gradual 180 I assume, back to his offspring.

Observation Details: Crazy experience with this Ruffed Grouse.  I originally saw it on the side of the road and I thought that it may have been hit by a car so I thought that I would see if if was OK.  It became very territorial and became aggressive.  It began to hiss at me and lunged at me a couple of times.  It began to fan out completely and both ruffs on the neck became exposed.  I came back through about an hour later and it was gone at that point.  But an amazing experience of a territorial display.  Pretty cool.

Observation Details: Merci à Réal et Ghyslaine Boulet pour cette découverte d'une Gélinotte huppée qui n'a jamais craint d'être observée par des humains. Elle a passé la journée le long de la route à manger des bourgeons dans les arbrisseaux au moins jusqu'en fin pm. Elle était également présente au même endroit la veille mais je ne l'ai par revue le lendemain.  Il s'agit d'un mâle adulte: huppe marquée, taches blanches en double sur le croupion (ici formant un coeur), collerette noire importante (ici repliée), ligne blanche qui part du lorum jusque derrière l'oeil, bande noire terminale qui n'est pas interrompue au centre par les rectrices centrales (qui sont mouchetés chez la femelle).

Picore également le sable, le ramenant vers lui jusqu'aux plumes noires de son cou qu'il expose.

Observation Details: I was walking on a trail and sudennly a grouse came strutting out of the underbrush and faced me showing off his black ruff and fanned grey tail with a black tip. Beautiful male ruffed grouse. You can still see the longer black feathers from his breeding plumage around his neck line. He was near the RV dump/trash station walking along the gravel road that is for staff use only, going towards the main road and the entrance to the dump station.  I watched him feeding all the way to the main road, where he scurried across it to the weeds next to the dump station driveway.  I did not see them, but the staff told me there is an adult female with 3 juveniles in that area also. Photos.

I made a video of it but don't think I can share that on ebird?

Locality: Cornell University - Fall Creek Suspension Bridge
Observation Details: Pecking around the non-campus entrance to the suspension bridge. Eventually flew up to 302 (I believe) directly across from the entrance and fed on buds in the yard. Eventually attempted to fly up onto the roof, but it was too steep and slippery, so the bird flapped around and fell. After that it perched on a lamp for a minute or two before hopping down and preening.

Media notes: While walking in the on/off rain on the Centennial Trail, about 1 mile in, I noted movement in the shadows.  The grouse and I caught each others attention simultaneously. Media notes: Gélinotte huppée, mâle adulte qui se prépare à manger  de petits bourgeon dans un arbrisseau.
Observation Details: Merci à Réal et Ghyslaine Boulet pour cette découverte d'une Gélinotte huppée qui n'a jamais craint d'être observée par des humains. Elle a passé la journée le long de la route à manger des bourgeons dans les arbrisseaux au moins jusqu'en fin pm. Elle était également présente au même endroit la veille mais je ne l'ai par revue le lendemain.  Il s'agit d'un mâle adulte: huppe marquée, taches blanches en double sur le croupion (ici formant un coeur), collerette noire importante (ici repliée), ligne blanche qui part du lorum jusque derrière l'oeil, bande noire terminale qui n'est pas interrompue au centre par les rectrices centrales (qui sont mouchetés chez la femelle).

Observation Details: Continuing. Mottled/striped White/tan/ rusty/brown/black uppers. Dark eye. Anterior throat/ chin/upper chest golden tan. Decurved bill. Small white patch behind eye & along bill. Rusty tail terminal black>/white thin bands. Slightly spiky crown. Vertical white lateral striPing. By Linda. Will add photos. Grouse may have been under the blind when we arrived. It walked out towards me from the far side of the blind and I eased to the ground, staying still. It wasn’t aggressive but walked across the path slowly. We stayed quiet as it foraged a bit. Bikers and another birder did get its attention, but it was never aggressive. What a memorable few minutes for a life bird for me. Susan

Cooperative but at times aggressive male. The bird didn't seem too aggressive while I was crouched down and facing it but when standing up and facing away the bird would chase me and occasionally jump at me, trying to peck and wing-slap me. I only stayed to record and photograph the bird for a few minutes as I didn't want to disturb it more than necessary, but it made it very difficult to leave. After I got in the car it went around and underneath the car for a few minutes but eventually went back to the edge of the road to forage. As soon as we started the car and began to move though, it ran directly at the car and started chasing alongside it so we had to stop as to not risk hitting it with one of the tires. I got out and was able to lure the bird towards me and away from the car before running back, hopping in, and driving away. The bird trailed behind the car (this time at a safe distance) for a few seconds before stopping when we got far enough away.

My tour was driving along road (towards St. John's) when two chicks ran into the road. I immediately recognized them as Ruffed Grouse chicks; we had great views of similarly-patterned Spruce Grouse chicks in Nova Scotia, but I knew that species isn't on the Avalon. Regardless, the pair was directly in my path, and I couldn't in that split-second swerve out of the way without endangering clients. The first chick flew up and over the hood, but I struck the second as it tried to lift off. Seeing it laying in the road in my rear view mirror, I pulled over. As I did, an adult with four additional chicks appeared at the margin. They scampered across the road, the adult briefly checking on the presumed-dead chick, and subsequently disappeared onto the adjacent hillside. One of my clients noticed the struck chick was twitching, so I sprinted down the road to check on it. It stood up as I approached, but I was able to scoop it up since it was dazed. It started peeping vigorously, and my brief inspection suggested the wings and legs were intact. Thinking it might survive, I scrambled up the hillside on hands and knees, hoping to catch to catch up with the family. I heard the adult cluck, turned to my left, and saw it standing fifteen feet from me. The chick peeped louder, so I put it on the ground and watched it take a few strides towards the calling adult. I exited at that moment because lingering would have jeopardized the reunion. I felt awful after the strike, but I am optimistic that the chick will survive the ordeal.

This Ruffed Grouse was fairly small  with a short, triangular crest and a long, fan-shaped tail. Short legs walking on snow.  It was intricately patterned with dark bars and spots on either a reddish-brown or grayish background. Black plumage down the side of the neck continue onto the body  belly. The tail is finely barred, with one wide, black band near the tip. The bird was found at Robert Shaw's house. Territorial ad aggressive.

Media notes: This was one of those classic extremely aggressive birds that you read about.  It literally came out of the woods and walked across the road like a chicken and attacked my pants legs and shoe laces. ( All I did was get out of my car and stand on the road in front of my car.  I never went into the woods.)   It was so aggressive that I only got a handful of photos with my 400 mm lens and then it was too close for me to focus on it.  In 1991 though it was all manual focus lenses.  It was a lot of fun though.  I don't know how birds like this could survive in the wild if they walk up to coyotes, bobcats, or even house cats !!!   (Original was slide film later digitized.)

Observation Details: Male heard drumming near camp from day #1 and first identified by Simon Marcel. Later that day Simone Littledale, Carter Strope and I went bushwacking in search of the bird and were able to find its drumming spot, a partially decayed moss covered log laden with some kind of shelf mushroom. Though we didn't see it drum there as it walked off after we found it, Carter noted a pile of scat at that exact spot which he thought indicated this was a display site rather just a perch. Later in camp when we told the others, Joachim Bertrands had the idea based on his guiding work in Borneo with Bird-of-Paradise lek hides to build a hide so we could view the grouse drumming up-close. That evening Simon, Carter, Joachim, Aiva and I went off and constructed a hide out of sword fern and fir branches, with some very conveniently salvaged netting which just happened to be within 5 feet of the blind spot. We also cleared a small trail leading to the blind of any twigs and sticks which might crack underfoot and give us away.  Day #2 a number of us quietly snuck into place with great anticipation and found the grouse perched on its log. In a very cool turn of events though, while waiting silently, a Pacific Marten came in nearly over our heads and sprinted over to the log, flushing the grouse which seemed at the time (and we later confirmed) to have gotten away unscathed. A few other attempts were made throughout the day to see if the bird returned which it did periodically, and late that evening Carter was able to see it drum before a Goshawk buzzed overhead.  Day #3 some of us had already headed back to Victoria while other (read; nearly all) of us were fighting wicked hangovers and not inclined to go stakeout a blind at the crack of dawn. Fueled by ire, Redbull (sponsor me), and being able to clearly hear the bird drumming from my tent, I went out on my own, going in barefoot so as to make as little noise as possible. The bird was there, the blind was effective, and I think the videos below speak for themself.  Really enjoyed getting to crack the code on Ruffed Grouse with my friends and excited to see if I can't replicate this again in other areas!

Observation Details: First found by Casey G. earlier this afternoon. RUGR exhibiting “tame grouse” behavior. Located the RUGR at 19:41 and left at 19:43. I took some photos but when the bird started to approach me, I didn’t want to agitate or alarm him, so I moved away and left. I watched him go off into the brush in an empty lot. Hoping he stays safe as it appears from others’ accounts he has crossed the road several times throughout the day.

Locality: Quartier le Radar, La Tuque CA-QC (47.9022,-74.6523)

Observation Details: I was probably there an hour before I found the grouse (my first time finding a grouse here, after missing multiple times last year).  One of the more memorable, cool, and yet weird bird experiences I've had. Although originally he was about 25' back in the woods (after I'd been looking for probably an hour), the grouse came gradually closer, eventually close enough that I could have touched him. Other than going nearer to the road's edge when he was 25' deep in the woods, I didn't approach him, but he approached me. He definitely started following me--at first, feeding quietly through the woods and walking the same way I did, then when I turned around and walked back (to see what he'd do), he turned around and followed me. Once he came out into the road, he definitely followed me--and I had to be very careful when I left, to be sure he was away from my car and back in the woods. Many photos, audio.
Sitting on side of highway.  Wandered off into woods as I left.

Observation Details: Tracked down Casper on my second try. Or rather, he tracked ME down. Same coordinates as posted by Lisa on 12/19, and I agree with Chris Floyd’s 12/27 comment that he is perhaps best seen from the car, which was great for a rainy day like today. Driving slowly in the expected area I suddenly noticed him in the rear view mirror, trotting down the road after me. I stopped and he walked along the drivers side of the car about ten feet away, so great pics. First one I’ve seen in the wild!

I've watched videos of tame behaving Ruffed Grouse, but never experienced one for myself until today! While driving Kimbles Road I saw this individual at the roadside; as I slowed to catch a glimpse it actually flew towards my vehicle and the others that stopped behind me. The bird then continued to walk in the road approaching any vehicles that slowed down. I left my car and chased it back into the forest hoping that it would decide to avoid this surprisingly busy road.

Locality: Waterton Lakes NP--Stables and Camp Columbus

Observation Details: Casper was a no-show for almost 20 minutes and then he intimately introduced himself and developed a case of severe separation anxiety that culminated with him actually accompanying me INSIDE my car as part of an aggressive adoption action campaign.  In what can only be described as a Jekyll and Hyde interlude, Casper the Friendly Grouse put on quite a show on the sandy dirt runway for his photo shoot, but as soon as I tried to leave a feathered switch flipped and the film turned Hitchcockian as he became Oscar the Grouchy Grouse.  Each time I turned to leave he unleashed an aggressive dual assault, alternating between fiendish foot pecking and shin slam dancing.  Oscar chased me to my car and after I got inside I quickly found I could not safely shut the low sitting Camry car door without making contact with my angry new friend.  He seized this moment to quickly hop onto the rocker panel, then my lap, and then the passenger’s seat!  In fear of possibly getting pecked in the face I immediately exited the car and thankfully Oscar followed me as I high tailed it Roadrunner style down the dirt lane with my feather friend hot on my tail.   Once he was about 75 feet from the car I beat feet back to the Camry and he chased, but I bested him by a good enough margin to safely shut the door behind me this time.  From my rear view mirror I watched Oscar run after my car as I drove off and when the gap between us increased he took flight after the car.  I was thrilled to see as I was passing a bend in the lane that he, flying in a cloud of dust behind me, decided to abandon his pursuit.  This will definitely go down as my most bizarre birding experience!

Continuing. Mottled/striped White/tan/ rusty/brown/black uppers. Dark eye. Anterior throat/ chin/upper chest golden tan. Decurved bill. Small white patch behind eye & along bill. Rusty tail terminal black>/white thin bands. Slightly spiky crown. Vertical white lateral striPing. By Linda. Will add photos. Grouse may have been under the blind when we arrived. It walked out towards me from the far side of the blind and I eased to the ground, staying still. It wasn’t aggressive but walked across the path slowly. We stayed quiet as it foraged a bit. Bikers and another birder did get its attention, but it was never aggressive. What a memorable few minutes for a life bird for me. Susan

Observation Details: I was alone on trail, actually standing in the bird blind for a good 10 minutes with no sign of the bird.  Then it suddenly jumped into the blind with me and tried to peck my boot.!!! I slowly backed out of the blind and quietly walked back down the trail while speaking gently and the bird followed me making quiet cooing type noises. It stopped and ate some grassy leaves once. I continued slowly towards the parking lot,  and he accompanied me for awhile before melting into the tall grasses.

Media notes: This looks like a dead chicken but the grouse is foraging and eating the buds in the birch tree
Observation Details: Flew in during this count. Scrounging around under the shrubs for food like one did the other day. Today, though, everything has a 1-2 inch layer of snow covering it. Two days ago I observed a grouse picking at shoots, green grass and the green leaves of exposed weeds.   Two of these, after a bit of foraging hunkered down under a shrub and puffed themselves up so big against the below-freezing temps that they looked like they would pop. You could hardly see their heads.they were just big blobs of feathers. They reminded me of puffer fish. The third bird continued foraging by flying up into the birch tree and began munching on buds from the birch and the adjacent flowering plum tree.

Ce matin, un mâle arrive dans la cour arrière marchant lentement, d'une façon pompeuse... La collerette gonflée, la queue en roue, il se pavane de long en large de la cour cherchant du regard une femelle qui pourrait être dans le secteur. Il semble n'avoir aucune spectatrice, du moins de notre point de vue. Au bout d'une quinzaine de minutes, le mâle dégonfle son plumage et se juche dans un bouleau pour s'alimenter. Cet individu possède un plumage intermédiaire entre une forme grise et une forme rousse. Le corps est gris. Par contre, la queue complètement rousse. C'est la première fois que nous observons ce type de plumage. Donc, c'est aussi « un new boy in town ». Parade nuptiale photographiée et filmée. (CC).

casper the friendly grouse! couldn't find him for an hour or so. on a hunch, let my car idle for about a couple minutes as I was about to leave, and sure enough he sauntered right over. right next to the pull-out just before the road crosses the brook.  If you are trying to photograph this fella, I highly recommend bringing a lens that goes wider than 100mm equivalent on full frame, or else you will have to keep backing up while he follows you!

Observation Details: Watched these two birds interact with each other in my backyard on the lawn, close to a bushline. They stayed close to each other usually necks up-stretched, until one would jump into the air and put it feet out toward the other and sometimes they both jumped up and did this display but they never seemed to touch or hurt one another. This went on for at least 10 minutes until one bird flew away and the other walked off into the bush. The same bird always stayed  slightly "up hill" of the other and moved back and forth as if to impede the forward motion of the other bird?

This is a bird I will never forget. As soon as I pulled up around the bend, it came running out of the woods towards my car. After that, it would not leave my side for the next 45 minutes (except for when I sprinted away, then it decided it could eat some leaves on the side of the road). This bird gets so close to you that you have to use the widest angle lens on your phone if you want to photograph it at eye level. It also did hit me once which was upsetting.

OMG. THE THUMPING IS SO FLIPPING COOL. I arrived at dawn and parked by the stream at 42.027823, -73.140312. Walked west to the small 4/5 marker. First noticed the subsonic thump thump thump, a bit distant, as a resonation in my carotid arteries, mistaking it for a jumpy heartbeat. With a few more rounds I was able to locate the source, more clearly and louder, on the south side of the road about a hundred feet beyond the sign, but I could not see it. I then used Cody's trick: this bird gets especially territorial with cars! I drove by slowly, backed up and did it again, and sure enough the bird popped right out to investigate. I was then able to watch it walk back to the downed tree for displays, more thumps, and general amazement.   After seeing the Sandhill Crane just down the road, the homeowner came out and shared that a few years ago her husband had an ongoing relationship with a grouse that got especially territorial about his woodsplitter (the thumps!) and would come right next to it to defend his turf. With some care the bird could even be picked up in the hand and let down again without much fuss.  See other checklist for more photos: https://ebird.org/checklist/S107089911  First description from George Edwards is a fun read: https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/56896007

Accidentally flushed from the ground in the bushes between us and the neighbors, by our pole-mounted satellite dish, at about 10:40 AM. It flew toward the backyard, and Dad spotted it in the bushes back there a short while later. It hung out there for about 45 minutes, giving us great views. Finally, around 11:30 AM, it strolled through the leaf litter at the edge of the backyard and disappeared from view behind the trunks of the big pine trees. I think this is actually my first sighting of this species in our yard, though I have seen them several times in our woods.

Observation Details: While gardening a family of ruffed grouse walked through the yard and into the garden. The little ones did not seem to mind me there and explored the garden.  They were able to flutter and jump up onto different objects in the garden. The mother was trying to keep an eye on her little brood and move them along by calling to them, but did not try to distract me.  They eventually followed their mother out of the garden and into the surrounding woods.

His name is Franklin. Very calm adult male walking on and along side the path, not startled by us or cyclists. Aged/Sexed by the visible black ruff. We could hear him coo and he was feeding on the dandelion and other leaves. At the closest was less than two feet away. Half a mile west of the parking lot. Observation Details: Il s'agit d'un mâle adulte: huppe marquée, taches blanches en double sur le croupion (ici formant un coeur), collerette noire importante (ici repliée), ligne blanche qui part du lorum jusque derrière l'oeil, bande noire terminale qui n'est pas interrompue au centre par les rectrices centrales (qui sont mouchetés chez la femelle).

Elle a passé la journée le long de la route à manger des bourgeons dans les arbrisseaux au moins jusqu'en fin pm. Elle était également présente au même endroit la veille mais je ne l'ai par revue le lendemain. Media notes: This bird was giving a distraction display.
Observation Details: This bird surprised me by running across the road in front of me. She was crouched down with her wings spread. She moved her wings rapidly from dorsal to ventral and made an odd, high pitched, rapid whimpering call. I had never seen a Ruffed Grouse use a distraction display, but that seemed to be what this behavior was.  I have reported this species before and given references for its occurring and breeding in this area. It should be added to Sanpete County's list of breeding birds that are here throughout the year.

Alors que je scrutais un parterre de coupe depuis la route, une gélinotte est sortie de la forêt derrière moi et a commencé a picoré le sol complètement à découvert. Si je me fis à sa large collerette, il s'agit de toute évidence d'un mâle. Afin qu'il ne se fasse pas frapper par une éventuelle voiture, je l'ai repoussé dans la forêt. Mais il en est ressorti moins de cinq minutes plus tard et a recommencé à se nourrir (ou à consommer du gravier?) en cherchant visiblement ma compagnie. Alors que j'étais accroupi pour la photographier, il s'est même approché à un mètre de moi! Étrange comportement!

This bird approached the car as soon as I stopped. When I got out to take its picture, it approached me, coming within half a metre. It did not appear to be defending territory; it did not display or peck. It just seemed curious, even more than a blue-footed booby I met in the Galapagos. When I backed up to keep it in frame with my telephoto lens, it followed me. When I drove away, it ran and flew after the car. I was sorry to go.

Observation Details: Un individu tambourine (donc mâle?) derrière notre tente. Puis, avant de quitter le site vers midi et demi, nous le voyons qui se baigne dans le sable derrière la voiture. Il se recouvre le dos de sable en utilisant ses plumes secondaires et tertiaires comme petite pelle et en faisant une drôle de semi-roulade. Picore également le sable, le ramenant vers lui jusqu'aux plumes noires de son cou qu'il expose.

Adult bird with at least two very small babies, possibly more in  the woods. We happened onto this female who froze out in a grassy driveway and clucked. Then she displayed (distraction?) by puffing out her breast feathers and clucking more. She walked into the edge of the trees but returned out into the grass to fluff out and cluck repeatedly again. One tiny brown ball of a baby we hadn't seen in the grass near our feet flushed suddenly to the left toward the trees and then another also flushed to the right. The hen kept up her clucking as we walked back to the car in her full view. She walked into the woods as we drove away.

Incredible encounter with one aggressive male!!! Stopped to listen to singing warblers only to be approached by a clucking male. After a few minutes of him following me around, I sat down to try and photograph him only to have him hop up on my legs! I sat with the bird for about 20 minutes before he began to get aggressive, prompting me to leave him alone. At one point he proceeded to take a big dump, luckily right off of my knee, narrowly missing me. What an awesome bird encounter.

Locality: Rouyn-Noranda, Rivière Mouilleuse ouest, Petit ours (SA14M2)
Observation Details: Cet individu était grandement agité puisqu'il nous chargeait tout en lançant des chuintements puissants, décrivant des cercles sur de courtes distances avant de charger à nouveau tout en déployant sa collerette et sa queue en éventail. Nous lui avons laissé le passage et avons fait un détour sans observer de poussins. C'est certainement l'épais couvert d'herbes qui nous empêchaient de vois sa progéniture. Le tout se déroule dans un vieux chemin forestier d'hiver menant à des îlots forestiers.

Beautiful male ruffed grouse. You can still see the longer black feathers from his breeding plumage around his neck line. He was near the RV dump/trash station walking along the gravel road that is for staff use only, going towards the main road and the entrance to the dump station.  I watched him feeding all the way to the main road, where he scurried across it to the weeds next to the dump station driveway.  I did not see them, but the staff told me there is an adult female with 3 juveniles in that area also. Photos.

Ruffed Grouse!!!  This was a PHENOMENALLY close (lifer) encounter with a very special species for Indiana. I sincerely hope this isn’t the only Ruffed Grouse I see here in my lifetime. Jonathan and I shared the experience with our buds, Kris and Logan Lakins, and coincidentally, three other birders (Mona C., Chris N., and Jeremiah O.). No planned “field trip.”  We spent over 2 hours searching the area for the grouse without luck. We were already on the road when Jeremiah messaged he had it, and then we turned around and rushed back up the path on foot. The lapse in time between calling off the search and heading back to the location was about 20 minutes. The experience was breathtaking — and not for the running/speed-walking!  Description… Brighter rufous coloration on the tail and neck. Thick black subterminal stripe on a long tail. Vertical black barring on its sides with white between. Chestnut eyes with super cool “eyelashes.” Gorgeous bird in general. The most ornately spangle-patterned brown back I’ve ever seen. Looking closely, there were little cream-colored hearts on its back. Black feathers around the long neck feathers that looked like a flattened ruff. Size-wise, it was surprisingly bigger than I thought it would be; bigger than a Bobwhite. It was remarkably camouflaged from a distance. I believe the bird we saw to be a male due to the unbroken black stripe on its long tail.  Behavior… When we saw the Ruffed Grouse, it was walking on the forest floor about 15 feet away from us. It stayed flightless the entire time. It frequently called quietly, making some “pew” calls in twos and threes and single cat-like purrs (whuuuut!). The bird perched on a fallen log to watch us before approaching; it got within two feet of our group while we stood quietly in place at the forested edge. The Brown County Epic, a mountain-biking event, was happening while we were there, so two to three cyclists would occasionally pass by and spook the grouse further back into the woods. We didn’t even need our binoculars. Unbelievable. It played Inspector Jacques Clouseau with us and every now and again would grab and yeet leaves. I’m honestly flabbergasted by the inquisitiveness of this bird.  Habitat… mature forest with mixed hardwoods. I noticed lots of tulip poplars, shagbark hickory, and maples and plenty of debris/bark on the ground and understory. My tree ID is limited, though.  Our observation was from a stationary position. I made brief descriptive notes on my phone in the field and typed up more details later that evening. Our time was spent solely with the grouse, hence the low count for other species. I logged others earlier while searching (https://ebird.org/checklist/S120204215). The grouse experience filled my cup, so to speak, so much so that I didn’t go birding again for days. The rabbit hole of learning more about this species kept me delightfully occupied.  This checklist was hidden from output for a month, honoring the request of the person who relocated the/a previously reported grouse and shared the information confidentially. I didn’t make the rules.

2nd try.  I parked at the second parking area, the sandy one close to where the stream crosses under the road.  I then walked back and forth between that parking area and the first one (east).  On the first lap between the parking areas, I heard but did not see what sounded like a RUGR flush where the trail goes off to the north.  After a while, another birder joined, but left after awhile.  On the next lap, I heard a RUGR giving the 'poik' call faintly but close.  Merlin agreed.  I could hear it in the underbrush to the north of the road, but could not see it.  I got down on my knees and was able to see under some of the brush and spotted it.  It seemed to be aware of me and walked back and forth about 20 feet in, stopping now and then to stare at me.  I was able to spot some relatively 'clear-ish' spots on his back and forth route and was able to get some decent pics as he went by those spots.
Display; female was 3 feet away.

The male puffed himself up and displayed a little and gave a great show while clucking at me while trying to defend his chicks, soon both adults calmed down and retreated back into the brush. Observation Details: Dark bars on flanks and dark tail band. Warming, sunny day, approx 50 degrees F. While driving through a wooded area leaving Porter’s Cove., the bird crossed the gravel road in front of the car. I stopped and the bird walked along the road past the car, stopping near the right rear tire. When I pulled slowly forward the bird chased the car. When I got out of the car to take a photo, the bird began to pursue me, pecking at my shoes. It did not flee even when I approached it, but continued it’s aggressive behavior until I backed away.

Casper is back! After hearing a report by a non-birder about a friendly grouse, I went to investigate. He was hanging about a quarter mile farther down Indian Brook Road from previous sightings. About here 41.884156, -70.551928. Still as friendly as ever, came up to the car and hung out for quite a while. Light was fading fast so couldn't get great pics.

probable male. At stop 19  (48 deg. 04.864'N, 121 deg 23.612' W)  I got out of the car at 50 feet to the nearest vegetation.  Right after I opened the car door  I heard a faint, low-pitched noise "whaaaoo" that almost sounded like my creaky car door. Then I felt a tapping on my boot.  It was a Ruffed Grouse. It made the noise and periodic tapping during the entire 3 minute BBS stop. Then I walked away from the car and it followed a gravel road cut where USFS had mined gravel for the road bed. It was maybe me for 15 feet. I got back in the car after snapping the photo. Then I drove off. The bird followed me down the USFS road for maybe 150 feet, clearly feeling proud of itself for having driven the giant out of its territory
Mom with 8 chicks, crossing the road in front of me.

Locality: Algonquin Provincial Park, Nipissing, Unorganized, South Part CA-ON (45.5857,-78.3607)

Observation Details: Flew in during this count. Scrounging around under the shrubs for food like one did the other day. Today, though, everything has a 1-2 inch layer of snow covering it. Two days ago I observed a grouse picking at shoots, green grass and the green leaves of exposed weeds.   Two of these, after a bit of foraging hunkered down under a shrub and puffed themselves up so big against the below-freezing temps that they looked like they would pop. You could hardly see their heads.they were just big blobs of feathers. They reminded me of puffer fish. The third bird continued foraging by flying up into the birch tree and began munching on buds from the birch and the adjacent flowering plum tree.

Ce matin, un mâle arrive dans la cour arrière marchant lentement, d'une façon pompeuse... La collerette gonflée, la queue en roue, il se pavane de long en large de la cour cherchant du regard une femelle qui pourrait être dans le secteur. Il semble n'avoir aucune spectatrice, du moins de notre point de vue. Au bout d'une quinzaine de minutes, le mâle dégonfle son plumage et se juche dans un bouleau pour s'alimenter. Cet individu possède un plumage intermédiaire entre une forme grise et une forme rousse. Le corps est gris. Par contre, la queue complètement rousse. C'est la première fois que nous observons ce type de plumage. Donc, c'est aussi « un new boy in town ». Parade nuptiale photographiée et filmée. (CC).

Locality: Cape Breton Highlands NP--Warren Lake Trail

Observation Details: A little before the first bridge that goes over the Indian Brook river (about 0.5 miles from 3A entrance). There is a small pullout to park your car, if needed. I did not see the bird earlier, but saw it on my way out.   It was very cooperative. In fact, I would say very inquisitive (vs aggressive) as well. It kept following me and maintaining a distance less than the minimum focus distance of my telephoto lens that I had to switch to my portrait lens!

Seen from car at the side of the road after birding in Culee Experimental State forest. Feeding. Walked into shrub cover after we got out of the car. Photos.
Male displayed during the entire five minutes that it took him to cross the road.

Watched these two birds interact with each other in my backyard on the lawn, close to a bushline. They stayed close to each other usually necks up-stretched, until one would jump into the air and put it feet out toward the other and sometimes they both jumped up and did this display but they never seemed to touch or hurt one another. This went on for at least 10 minutes until one bird flew away and the other walked off into the bush. The same bird always stayed  slightly "up hill" of the other and moved back and forth as if to impede the forward motion of the other bird?

First noted female at 6:54PM, then noted the male in full courtship about 30 yards away. The male continued with fanned tail and full black ruff until 7:54 and started eating. The female had been standing in one place from 6:54 until 7:35 when she started to feed completely oblivious to the displaying male moving further away from him. Female flew to woods at 7:55, male was last noted at 7:50
Nesting on ground, 10 eggs.

OMG. THE THUMPING IS SO FLIPPING COOL. I arrived at dawn and parked by the stream at 42.027823, -73.140312. Walked west to the small 4/5 marker. First noticed the subsonic thump thump thump, a bit distant, as a resonation in my carotid arteries, mistaking it for a jumpy heartbeat. With a few more rounds I was able to locate the source, more clearly and louder, on the south side of the road about a hundred feet beyond the sign, but I could not see it. I then used Cody's trick: this bird gets especially territorial with cars! I drove by slowly, backed up and did it again, and sure enough the bird popped right out to investigate. I was then able to watch it walk back to the downed tree for displays, more thumps, and general amazement.   After seeing the Sandhill Crane just down the road, the homeowner came out and shared that a few years ago her husband had an ongoing relationship with a grouse that got especially territorial about his woodsplitter (the thumps!) and would come right next to it to defend his turf. With some care the bird could even be picked up in the hand and let down again without much fuss.  See other checklist for more photos: https://ebird.org/checklist/S107089911  First description from George Edwards is a fun read: https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/56896007

Observation Details: Il s'agit d'un mâle adulte: huppe marquée, taches blanches en double sur le croupion (ici formant un coeur), collerette noire importante (ici repliée), ligne blanche qui part du lorum jusque derrière l'oeil, bande noire terminale qui n'est pas interrompue au centre par les rectrices centrales (qui sont mouchetés chez la femelle).

Observation Details: Merci à Réal et Ghyslaine Boulet pour cette découverte d'une Gélinotte huppée qui n'a jamais craint d'être observée par des humains. Elle a passé la journée le long de la route à manger des bourgeons dans les arbrisseaux au moins jusqu'en fin pm. Elle était également présente au même endroit la veille mais je ne l'ai par revue le lendemain.  Il s'agit d'un mâle adulte: huppe marquée, taches blanches en double sur le croupion (ici formant un coeur), collerette noire importante (ici repliée), ligne blanche qui part du lorum jusque derrière l'oeil, bande noire terminale qui n'est pas interrompue au centre par les rectrices centrales (qui sont mouchetés chez la femelle).

Locality: New York 28N, Newcomb, New York, US (43.93, -74.03)
Observation Details: Female with at least 3 young — may have had more but we were unable to confirm.  We first spotted two chicks on the road and pulled over as they scurried down a bank to a stream, below.  When we looked down the bank, we could see at least one other chick as well as the mother.  The juveniles disappeared into the brush but the mother stood in the open for several minutes.
On the side of the East Loring Trail.  I was looking up toward the treetops, and nearly stepped on it.

Un individu tambourine (donc mâle?) derrière notre tente. Puis, avant de quitter le site vers midi et demi, nous le voyons qui se baigne dans le sable derrière la voiture. Il se recouvre le dos de sable en utilisant ses plumes secondaires et tertiaires comme petite pelle et en faisant une drôle de semi-roulade. Picore également le sable, le ramenant vers lui jusqu'aux plumes noires de son cou qu'il expose.
A surgit du bois en mode attaque pour protéger son petit

Observation Details: A total of five individual birds seen by the group on the drive down Tall Trees Road. Most birds  were around 1.5-3~4 miles down the road. First one flushed off the road and then the second one foraged along the road for a bit and then flew up into a tree next to the road giving excellent views. If I remember correctly the 3rd or 4th bird was sitting down on the side of the road and we pulled right up to it. Never have I seen 5 Ruffed Grouse in a single trip to Tall Trees to a pretty momentous occasion to share these birds with the CA Young Birders. Too cool!
Elles viennent manger du maïs près de la maison et repoussent les geais bleu qui s'approchent.

Locality: Port au Port Pen.--The Gravels Walking Trail
Observation Details: deceased... it was on the side of the road next to the entrance to the Gravels parking lot... I felt compelled to place it in another spot for fear birds of prey  or scavengers that might want to take it would run the risk of being hit by traffic. Even with my gloves on, I couldn't get over how warm its body still was, so it must have been just hit or died. When I got back to my car 2h45m later, its body was still there so I assume  no scavenger or BOP found it.

Observation Details: Cet individu était grandement agité puisqu'il nous chargeait tout en lançant des chuintements puissants, décrivant des cercles sur de courtes distances avant de charger à nouveau tout en déployant sa collerette et sa queue en éventail. Nous lui avons laissé le passage et avons fait un détour sans observer de poussins. C'est certainement l'épais couvert d'herbes qui nous empêchaient de vois sa progéniture. Le tout se déroule dans un vieux chemin forestier d'hiver menant à des îlots forestiers.

Observation Details: Pecking around the non-campus entrance to the suspension bridge. Eventually flew up to 302 (I believe) directly across from the entrance and fed on buds in the yard. Locality: Johnson Rd., West of Short Rd.
200–282 Birch Lake Rd, Sables-Spanish Rivers CA-ON 46.23125, -82.06589

Observation Details: I was probably there an hour before I found the grouse (my first time finding a grouse here, after missing multiple times last year).  One of the more memorable, cool, and yet weird bird experiences I've had. Although originally he was about 25' back in the woods (after I'd been looking for probably an hour), the grouse came gradually closer, eventually close enough that I could have touched him. Other than going nearer to the road's edge when he was 25' deep in the woods, I didn't approach him, but he approached me. He definitely started following me--at first, feeding quietly through the woods and walking the same way I did, then when I turned around and walked back (to see what he'd do), he turned around and followed me. Once he came out into the road, he definitely followed me--and I had to be very careful when I left, to be sure he was away from my car and back in the woods. Many photos, audio.
It was in a tree close to the feeders, it was eating buds in the tree. Later i flew to a birch tree in the yard and was feeding there. It left at 5:23

Casper is back! After hearing a report by a non-birder about a friendly grouse, I went to investigate. He was hanging about a quarter mile farther down Indian Brook Road from previous sightings. About here 41.884156, -70.551928. Still as friendly as ever, came up to the car and hung out for quite a while. Light was fading fast so couldn't get great pics.
This ruffed grouse should sign a modeling contract… because it allowed for great pictures!

I've watched videos of tame behaving Ruffed Grouse, but never experienced one for myself until today! While driving Kimbles Road I saw this individual at the roadside; as I slowed to catch a glimpse it actually flew towards my vehicle and the others that stopped behind me. The bird then continued to walk in the road approaching any vehicles that slowed down. I left my car and chased it back into the forest hoping that it would decide to avoid this surprisingly busy road.
Single bird, guarding territory aggressively and foraging near public walking/biking trail.
