Casper was a no-show for almost 20 minutes and then he intimately introduced himself and developed a case of severe separation anxiety that culminated with him actually accompanying me INSIDE my car as part of an aggressive adoption action campaign.  In what can only be described as a Jekyll and Hyde interlude, Casper the Friendly Grouse put on quite a show on the sandy dirt runway for his photo shoot, but as soon as I tried to leave a feathered switch flipped and the film turned Hitchcockian as he became Oscar the Grouchy Grouse.  Each time I turned to leave he unleashed an aggressive dual assault, alternating between fiendish foot pecking and shin slam dancing.  Oscar chased me to my car and after I got inside I quickly found I could not safely shut the low sitting Camry car door without making contact with my angry new friend.  He seized this moment to quickly hop onto the rocker panel, then my lap, and then the passenger’s seat!  In fear of possibly getting pecked in the face I immediately exited the car and thankfully Oscar followed me as I high tailed it Roadrunner style down the dirt lane with my feather friend hot on my tail.   Once he was about 75 feet from the car I beat feet back to the Camry and he chased, but I bested him by a good enough margin to safely shut the door behind me this time.  From my rear view mirror I watched Oscar run after my car as I drove off and when the gap between us increased he took flight after the car.  I was thrilled to see as I was passing a bend in the lane that he, flying in a cloud of dust behind me, decided to abandon his pursuit.  This will definitely go down as my most bizarre birding experience!

Heard two drumming off in the distance. A third was observed following us for a second time. It approached us when we first arrived, walking along beside us in the cover. Even "came to visit" my husband while he sat on a nearby log.  After a few minutes it did begin attacking us a few times, flying into our legs and such. Then it backed off and continued to keep an eye on us while we walked away. It then proceeded to try attacking our vehicle as we drove away. Unfortunately, the next day there was only a pile of feathers in that area.
45 minutes with bird along bike path. Magical moments in birding.

Locality: 88003-88015 New Rumley Road, Jewett, Ohio, US (40.369, -81.027)
Observation Details: I was alone on trail, actually standing in the bird blind for a good 10 minutes with no sign of the bird.  Then it suddenly jumped into the blind with me and tried to peck my boot.!!! I slowly backed out of the blind and quietly walked back down the trail while speaking gently and the bird followed me making quiet cooing type noises. It stopped and ate some grassy leaves once. I continued slowly towards the parking lot,  and he accompanied me for awhile before melting into the tall grasses.

Finally! I've been waiting for an attack grouse rather than the ones that flush beneath your feet unexpectedly. Continuing bold individual coming out of the woods  to fight me, on the north side of the road at the car turn-out located just before the road crosses Indian Brook. After our intimate photo sesh, he walked back into the woods, this time crossing the road to the south side.
#210 Baker year bird. FINALLY! A single female bird crawling an alder bush.

2nd try.  I parked at the second parking area, the sandy one close to where the stream crosses under the road.  I then walked back and forth between that parking area and the first one (east).  On the first lap between the parking areas, I heard but did not see what sounded like a RUGR flush where the trail goes off to the north.  After a while, another birder joined, but left after awhile.  On the next lap, I heard a RUGR giving the 'poik' call faintly but close.  Merlin agreed.  I could hear it in the underbrush to the north of the road, but could not see it.  I got down on my knees and was able to see under some of the brush and spotted it.  It seemed to be aware of me and walked back and forth about 20 feet in, stopping now and then to stare at me.  I was able to spot some relatively 'clear-ish' spots on his back and forth route and was able to get some decent pics as he went by those spots.

The habitat was dense, thick, low understory, a little over halfway from the trailhead to Lower Palisades Lake. I was walking back down the trail when I heard a strange, novel whining sound. Looked up to see what I thought at first was a hurt badger limping down the trail. When it lifted its head, I realized it was a grouse. As soon as this clicked, baby grouse began to flush out of the understory. I now realized the grouse was luring me away from its young. I didn't budge, and proceeded to take camera shots. The grouse did not like this. He turned, fanned his tail, activated his 'gills", and charged me. I held my ground, and amid my terror, managed to snap a couple photos. He slammed on the brakes less than 10 feet away, then proceeded to  try luring me away again. This time I obliged. After 100-150 feet or so, he turned off the trail into the understory, making a gradual 180 I assume, back to his offspring.

Continuing at pulloff on right just before bridge over Indian Brook. Appeared about 10 just as I was going to leave, having given up; chased my car from front as I was backing up toward bridge to get precise mileage to 3A; ran into cover off road as I backed into pulloff; then emerged, at first shyly, but eventually parading back and forth just below my open window. Seemed attracted to the car and unconcerned with me.

Locality: Superior National Forest, Tofte US-MN 47.62800, -90.78436 Moose Mountain
Observation Details: Saw all three on the trail as we hiked. Mother continued about 20’ further on trail before heading into the forest on the left. The two young ones flew into low branches on trees on the right side of the trail. Later the mother called them to the other side of the trail.

Weirdest grouse experience ever. The bird was sauntering down the dirt road and approached the car. It wouldn't leave. I eventually got out of the car, moving slowly and expecting the typical grouse explosive launch. Never happended!!!. I was able to approach within five feet and urge it away. Finally was able to "shoo" the bird off the road so I could exit. It was like it was a domestic chicken in disguise.

Crazy experience with this Ruffed Grouse.  I originally saw it on the side of the road and I thought that it may have been hit by a car so I thought that I would see if if was OK.  It became very territorial and became aggressive.  It began to hiss at me and lunged at me a couple of times.  It began to fan out completely and both ruffs on the neck became exposed.  I came back through about an hour later and it was gone at that point.  But an amazing experience of a territorial display.  Pretty cool.

While gardening a family of ruffed grouse walked through the yard and into the garden. The little ones did not seem to mind me there and explored the garden.  They were able to flutter and jump up onto different objects in the garden. The mother was trying to keep an eye on her little brood and move them along by calling to them, but did not try to distract me.  They eventually followed their mother out of the garden and into the surrounding woods.

Locality: Marais de la Rivière aux Cerises

Observation Details: Dark bars on flanks and dark tail band. Warming, sunny day, approx 50 degrees F. While driving through a wooded area leaving Porter’s Cove., the bird crossed the gravel road in front of the car. I stopped and the bird walked along the road past the car, stopping near the right rear tire. When I pulled slowly forward the bird chased the car. When I got out of the car to take a photo, the bird began to pursue me, pecking at my shoes. It did not flee even when I approached it, but continued it’s aggressive behavior until I backed away.

Locality: QC - Rochebaucourt - QC-397 à hauteur de Rivière Laflamme
